reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central “escape hatch” in the position: the Jones-style claim that with abundant/faster AGI labor, AI R&D can be rapidly reorganized so short-run complementarity (rho<0) relaxes toward rho≈0. If that move fails, the position’s case that compute bottlenecks only bite late is noticeably weakened, though the position also offers other independent counters (e.g., experiment efficiency gains, non-frontier extrapolation, multiple routes), so centrality is below 0.5. The critique’s argument is moderately strong: it plausibly points out that ‘reconfiguration’ itself often requires compute-heavy validation (full-stack trials, long-horizon evals, stability/safety checks), which could keep compute as a near-term gate and prevent fast compounding. However it doesn’t establish that these steps must be near-frontier or irreducibly sequential in the relevant regimes, so it weakens rather than refutes. Most claims are plausible and consistent with how ML infra changes typically work, so correctness is high. It is clear, focused, and provides concrete examples and an actionable evidential demand (break down compute-light vs compute-heavy reconfiguration with empirical analogues), with little fluff.
title: Reconfiguring AI R&D needs compute-intensive validation, so fast AGIs won’t speed it much
